rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The philosophical significance of the Ancient Mariner
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The phrase "Coleridge's philosophy of art" should be understood to include both his theory of plastic art and his theory of poetry. At times we have used "aesthetic theory" and "philosophy of art" loosely as interchangeable terms. This is because at first Coleridge seems not to have made a distinction between a theory of beauty and one of poetry, although later, of course, he did. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Coleridge, Samuel Taylor, 1772-1834. Rime of the ancient mariner

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The morphological effects of alloxan injection and the effect of insulin in alloxan diabetes in the rabbit
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] I wish to state here that I am only interested in the purely pancreatic factors, if any, in alloxan diabetes. It has been said bfrequently that the endocrine pancreas, besides producing insulin, may produce another hormone which, in turn, might produce hyjerglycaemia, or a fat-metabolizing hormone or anti-ketogenie hormone. Most of those who have worked on this subject have a tendency to consider that the alpha cell of the islet of Langerhans is, in the morphological field, the seat of this function. With the introduction of alloxan, which is a simple method of inducing selective necrosis of the beta cell of the islet, and with the development of histological technique in the last few years for the differential study of the islet cell, it would appear that a thorough study of this problem should be considered. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pathology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: gamma]-Rays of neutron capture studied with [beta-Ray spectrometer
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A method is described for using a b-ray spectrometer to measure the energies and intensities of the Y-rays emitted at the instant of capture of a thermal neutron by a nucleus. The method is applicable to very weak neutron capturers provided that they are available in large quantities, as well as to strong neutron capturers. Experiments were performed in which the capture Y-ray spectra of carbon, a weak capturer, and cadmium, a strong capturer, were observed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the effect of botulinum toxin on the transmission of nerve impulses
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Since the latest evidence indicates that the toxicity in botulism is due to a decrease in the production of acetylcholine by motor end plates and parasympathetic nerve endings with the toxin having no direct effect on the muscle or conduction of nerve impulses through the nerve trunk itself, it was decided to attempt to further test this assumption and to determine the mechanism by which the decrease is brought about. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Energy determination of the hard gamma-ray from gallium 72 by photo-disintegration in a Wilson cloud chamber
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A description is given of an automatic stereoscopic camera de-signed for cloud chamber photography. The design of other auxiliary apparatus for a cloud chamber is also presented. The details are given of a. method of hard gamma-ray determination involving the measurement of the ranges of photoprotons produced by the gamma radiation in a deuterium filled cloud chamber. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The formation and properties of three-dimensional polymers
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Vulcanized rubber is generally considered to possess a network structure which results from the presence of occasional cross-linkages between essentially linear polymeric molecules (1). The detailed structureof such three-dimensional polymers can be elucidated by consideration of the chemical processes by which the network is formed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of varying amounts of salt upon the microflora of pickled codfish
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Pickling of codfish is an important industry in Newfoundland, success in which is dependent upon a number of microbiological factors. These factors have not received adequate elucidation. Accordingly a study of the microbiological aspects of codfish pickling has been undertaken. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology, Agricultural

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Commodity controls and public policy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] This project briefly explores the circumstances which give rise to commodity controls and the role which public policy plays in their control and development. [...]

Trusts

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An Attempt to Locate Steroids in Tissues with Special Emphasis on The Distribution of Radio-Iodo-Estradiol in Cancer-Susceptible Mice
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] This present work is a contribution toward the solution of the problem of the "intermediary metabolism" of steroids. Of the two methodsused, histochemical and radioactive, the latter was by far the most productive. Even when some of the results were not up to expectations, the field has been cleared for further progress. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: De la possession dans le droit civil de la province de Québec
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] En arrivant au Canada, ma decision etaitprise: j'ecri-rais sur la possession. Cette decision a trouve encore un autre motif de justification, des que j'ai su qu'aucun travail d'ensemble n'existait sur la possession, dans le Droit Civil de la Province de Quebec. Cette circonstance, m'offrait la possibilite de satisfaire mon desir de remplir une lacune dans mon 6duration juridique, en meme temps que de combler, quoique d'une maniere imparfa ite, une lacune dans le bibliographic quebecoise. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Law

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: On the biology of the Arctic char
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The object of this work is to record some of the facta known on the biology of the Arctic Char, Salvelinus alplnus (Linn.), found in the waters of the eastern Canadian Arctic. Data presented werecollected by the writer during the suramer of 1948, when Operations were conducted off the Baffin Island coast for connaercial fishing of this char. Observations were made on habits of Salvelinus, recordscompiled of length and sex from random samples of the catch, and collections made of stomach Contents, from which something of local planktonic types was learned, and of otollths and scales, for thedetermination of age in the char. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Arctic char

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The evaluation of the breeding potential of full-sisters in the domestic fowl
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The relative importance of the average egg production record of families of full-sisters in breeding for egg productionwas demonstrated by Taylor and Lerner (1938). Juli (1947) obtained egg production records on unculled progeny of selected fullsister dams mated to the same sire but there are no published reports of progeny records of unselected full-sister dams matedto the same sire . It is the purpose of this study to determine the relative breeding potential of full-sisters with egg productionabove the family average as compared to those below the family average.[..]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Poultry -- Breeding

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The formation and fate of the Thyroid hormone
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Thus by 1896 it had been clearly demonstrated that the thyroid elaborates a hormone possessing a marked effect on bodily processes and that this hormone is an iodinated organic molecule present in protein combination in the thyroid gland. This basic hypothesis being established, the subsequent sections of this survey will cover the literature on the mechanism of this physiological activity and the available data on the nature of the iodinated Compounds involved. This discussion will be concerned therefore with the entry of iodine into the thyroid;its incorporation into organic molecules, resulting in the formation of the thyroid hormone; the mechanism of the release of the hormone into the blood; and its distribution and fate in the peripheral tissues. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Kinetic studies in solution and in the solid phase. : Pt. I. The cis-trans isomerization of azobenzene in solution. Pt. II. The thermal decomposition of styrene-butadiene popcorn polymer
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Most of the reactions which have been studied in Solution are bimolecular and as a result little is known about the effect of solvents on unimolecular reactions. A survey of existing data (1) reveals, further, that in most of the reactions, for which the kinetics havebeen investigated from the point of view of solvent effect, the reactants are either ions or highly polar molecules. Quantitative application of theories of solvent effect has been almost entirely limited to these types of reactions. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Aspects of English naval history in the fourteenth century
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] English seapower did not hinge on the outcome of a few major engagements, but on the ability of the crown to maintain a fleet, sufficiently large at all times,to ward off the attacks of the Erench and their allies. Thus the fruits of victory werethrown away after Sluys, because the King did not keep his navy in readiness to repulse the Erench and Castilian squadrons which wereattacking the seaports of his dominions.The study of naval administration during the period is of peculiar interest, because it throws considerable light onto the constitutional development of England. In this connection the struggle between the admirals' courts and the courts of common law was reflectedin the conflicting prerogatives of the King's officers charged with the administration of the navy and the Citizens of the seaports. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Great Britain -- History, Naval
Great Britain. Royal Navy -- History

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Collective bargaining in the wartime Crown companies of Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The corporate management system which was utilized by the Government of Canada in order to meet the demands of war involved that Government, both directly and indirectly, with the Labour Movement. This thesis attemptsto outline the development of collective bargaining in that segment of the war economy which was directly controlled by Government through agencies which it created; that is, this thesis will deal with the salient pointsof collective bargaining in those wartime creatures of the Dominion of Canada - the crown companies which were established by the Department of Munitions and Supply in order to prosecute the war. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: CANADA -- LABOUR
Collective Bargaining

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Galsworthy's treatment of Social Problems and Ideas in His Drama
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The long plain with periodic and rather uninteresting undulations, which might be said to represent the level of nineteenth century English drama, is broken by one central eminence, where T.W Robertson introduced more modernstage methods and reality into the drama with plays like David Garrick (1864), Society (1865) and Caste(1867).Robertson had considerable dramatic power and his plays are undoubtedly interesting, but his noteworthiness is partlydue to his treatment of certain social ideas upon the stage. After this eminence the long plain rises gently in the 1880's to the moderately impressive foothills of Henry Arthur Jones and Sir Arthur Ting Pinero, which lie before the escarpment of Shaw and the rolling hills of Wilde, Barrie,Granville Barker, Galsworthy and their contemporaries.The plays of all these men are high points, affordingdifferent prospects, and from the high ground of Galsworthy there are many long views. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Food Science and Agricultural Chemistry
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of some chemical changes of proteins of foods during storage with particular reference to lysine
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Food dehydration has been an occupation of man from the earliest times. The ancients dried fish and meat in the sun as a means of preservation, and sun dried fruits have beenfamiliär foods for centuries. More recently the commercial dehydration of a wide ränge of food products has become one of the worldTs major food preservation Industries. Commercialfood dehydration appears still to be in its infancy In spite of these recent developments.Several advantages of drying foods to a low moisture content are obvious, such as facilitation of transportation,convenience in use, Prolongation of the storage period and decrease of storage space requirement. On the other hand, a few disadvantages remain, Chief of which is the decrease ofpalatability and nutritional quality of many dehydrated products during storage. Research during recent years has vastly improved the keeping qualities of dried foods, butthe fundamental causes of many types of spoilage are by no means completely understood. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Acetylcholine Sythesis and Carbohydrate Metabolism
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Although the action of acetylcholine (ACh) had been known to physiologists for many years, it was not until 1929 that Dale and Dudley(27) Isolated ACh from animal tissues for the first time. In 1936 Quastel, Tennenbaumand Wheatley(87) demonstrated the presence in brain cortex slices of an enzyme system which synthesizes ACh, and showed that the synthesis is closely associated with the aerobiobreakdown of glucose. It was found also that glucose can be replaced to some extent by lactate or pyruvate, but still only under aerobic condition. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Exchange of radioiodine between inorganic and organic iodides
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In an exchange reaction two compounds having one atom in common are mixed and an interchange of the common atom takes place between the two compounds. The extent of the exchange is measured by making the common atom in one of the compounds detectable as a radioactive or stable isotope, the former being preferred because it is more readily traced. At the end of the reaction time the two compounds are separated and the distribution of the isotope measured. If complete exchange has taken place each compound has the same proportion of isotope, but if no exchange has occurred all the isotope is found in the original compound. The exchange reaction has been recognized as a valuable tool in chemistry, particularly in organic chemistry, because it gives direct information regarding bond reactivities and reaction mechanisms. The reaction offers an excellent method of studying some of the most fundamental properties of chemical compounds because it provides a remarkably simple system. Since the reactants and products are chemically identical there is no heat of reaction, only an energy of activation; concentrations remain constant and there are no interfering products or by-products. It is, therefore, somewhat surprising to note that the mechanism of the exchange reaction in solution has not been completely studied. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The life history and ecology of the cod-worm, Porrocaecum decipiens (Krabbe) 1878, in Canadian Atlantic waters
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Atlantic Cod, Gadus callarias Linnaeus 1758, in inshore Canadian waters is commonly infected with an ascarid which most frequently occurs in the musculature of the host. Although it is unlikely that the worm is harmful to man (Martin, 1920; Kahl, 1938), the aesthetic distraction confronting a human consumer is readily apparent. The widespread occurrence of this worm in an important commercial fish presents a grave problem not only to the fresh-fish industry but also to the canned-fish industry in the Atlantic Maritime provinces of Canada. Fish producers are frequently compelled to employ personnel whose sole function is the removal of worms from fillets and this procedure is obviously expensive. It has been conservatively estimated that this infection is the cause of an annual loss to the fishing industry of approximately two hundred and fifty thousand dollars. The situation was so serious that in 1945 it was decided to study the life history of the parasite in an effort to disclose some method of control[...]Although the primary purpose of this investigation at the time of its conception was the discovery of some method of control of the parasite, the body of the investigation as presented in this paper soon developed into a study of the life history of the worm[...]It will be later seen that the course of the investigation has led the author not only to a consideration of the developmental history of the worm but also to a consideration of its ecological behaviour.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Nematodes

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Column strength of an aluminum alloy section
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis is written to show that within the elastic limit of the material, the behavior of columns can be predicted with reasonable accuracy by means of the well-known Secant Formula or a combination of the Secant Formula and the Initial Curvature Formula. Nine aluminum alloy columns (Alcan 26S-T) in lengths ranging from 7’-0” to l’-6” have been tested with both central and eccentric loads, and measurements of stresses and deflections taken at intervals during the tests. These results are compared with the theoretical values to show the accuracy of the formulas. The application of these results to the establishment of design formulas is also discussed, and future lines of investigation are suggested.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Civil Engineering & Applied Mechanics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation of the ether and ligroin extracts of white spruce bark
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The present research, the second in a series on the constitution of white spruce bark, is concerned with the extraneous components, or those that are extracted by chemically inert solvents. Research on such materials was initiated in the hope of finding valuable constituents in sufficient quantity to warrant the recovery of the extractives on a commercial scale, because at present bark is a major waste product of the Pulp and Paper Industry. Since previous workers in this field were limited in the extent of their investigations by the inadequate quantity of bark which they studied, the present research was commenced on a pilot plant scale. In order that comparative studies could be made with past or future work, the bark was peeled from the trees in the woods rather than collected from river-run pulp logs. The methanol extract from about 600 pounds of bark was precipitated with water and this precipitate was extracted with ligroin and diethyl ether. [...] Consequently, the research resolved itself into three major tasks, the identification of the neutral esters, the separation and study of the neutral unsaponifiable matter and the investigation of the nature of the fatty acids present. Throughout the project, attempts were made to obtain strictly quantitative yields of the various components. In this connection the decision to conduct the work on a large scale has been repeatedly vindicated because certain constituents are present only in minute quantity.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A method for the rapid isolation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The demonstration of the tubercle bacillus by Robert Koch in 1882, as the etiological agent of tuberculosis led to developments in technique for the isolation of the bacilli from suspected material. Because of the scarcity of organisms in some specimens, concentration methods were devised to give a more delicate demonstration of the bacilli than was possible by direct smear or culture. The increasing importance of bacteriological methods for diagnosis in many cases of suspected tuberculosis has given a stimulus to the study of such procedures. In spite of the voluminous literature that has been published there is still a need for a more satisfactory method for the demonstration of the presence of the tubercle bacilli in pathological specimens. The development of nutritive media has made great progress since the time of Koch, but there still remains much to be desired from the point of view of time required for the appearance of colonies and the initiation of growth from minimal inocula. A concentration method based on the flotation principle of Lange and Nitsche (1909) utilizing oil as the agent, and the medium described by Dubos (1945), using Tween and albumin were investigated for this problem, with the view of achieving a more satisfactory method for the demonstration of the tubercle bacillus.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Le réel et l’imaginaire dans les contes et romans d’Alexandre Arnoux, 1918-1947
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Le President de l’Academie Goncourt en 1948 était Alexandre Arnoux.1 II a produit une oeuvre considérable, et en qualité et en quantité, et semble jouir actuellement du plein épanouissement de son génie: Algorithme. qu’il a publie en 1948, sera bientÔt suivi d’un ouvrage sur Paris, maintenant sous presse, dont le titre n’est pas encore définitif. Colloques allemands est en préparation, et a déjà paru en partie dans l’hebdomadaire Carrefour (novembre-décembre 1948). A part ces ouvrages, Alexandre Arnoux a fait imprimer 19 volumes de romans et nouvelles, sept volumes d’essais, huit pièces de théâtre (dont une traduction de Goethe et deux de Calderon de La Barca), six volumes classés comme “Divers”, une édition des Stances, Sonnets, Chansons et Rondeaux de Voiture, précédée d’une notice, et un récit pour enfants. Alexandre Arnoux n’a fondé aucune école, mais c’est un observateur perspicace de la période qui entre dans l’histoire sous le nom de “l’entre-deux-guerres”, et ses observations forment le point de départ ou le fonds de la série de contes, de nouvelles, de romans, et d’essais anecdotiques qu’il convient de nommer simplement “contes et romans”. Les trente années entre 1918 et 1947 ont fourni tout ce qu’il y a de représentatif jusqu‘ ici dans son oeuvre.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Arnoux, Alexandre -- Criticism and interpretation
